subject: Re: Parralel Systems
msgSnippet: I am currently working on a character set for Senior Quickscript. Most of the letters have more than one form (Roe or Are has four) even some of the vowels
messageBody:
I am currently working on a character set for Senior Quickscript.
Most of the letters have more than one form (Roe or Are has four)
even some of the vowels (upward and downward Utter or A, the normal
and connected form At or As. Including the namer dot and angled
brackets it has about 70 characters.
I really don't think that Kingsley Read ever imagined computers
as they are now. Besides, Junior Quickscript looks to much like an
unnassebled puzzle.


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, pgabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
>
> I am not sure I agree with the suggestion that junior QS was
intended to
> be the default alphabet with senior QS for handwriting alone. I
think
> of junior as being for beginners while they are still getting used
to
> the alphabet. I find that senior makes more distinctive word
shapes,
> which are easier to remember without the necessity of "sounding
the
> letters out," i.e. sight recognition is improved, and it may even
may
> make reading faster to those adept in senior.
>
> I see the distinction between senior and junior as similar to that
of
> printed T.O. and cursive T.O. In the past, cursive was not
practical to
> use for printed material so almost everything was printed in
> disconnected letters. Cursive writing was reserved for
handwriting.
> But that is no longer necessary. Computer technology should be
able to
> make the use of senior forms relatively easy, so why should we not
use
> the senior form in material printed for proficient readers?
>
> It is my understanding that Arabic letters change their shape
depending
> on their location in a word without causing distress to Arabic
readers.
> Should not QS have the flexibility to use the senior forms in
printed
> material if the writer prefers it? The senior forms are more
fluid and
> aesthetically appealing to me than the junior version of the
alphabet.
>
> Paige
>
> Ph.D. wrote:
> >
> > Del Ray skribis:
> > >
> > > Dr-o Phil kaj Tim:
> > >
> > > I can't imagine that anyone seriously thinks that QS
> > > might supplant Latin for writing English. Shaw might
> > > have thought that about Shavian, but did Kingsley
> > > Read even think that about QS?
> >
> > That's a good question. Shavian was intended to be
> > the default writing system for English, but what did
> > Read intend for QS? I've always assumed that he
> > intended junior QS to become the default alphabet
> > for English with senior QS as a shorthand for handwriting.
> >
> > --Ph. D.
> >
> >
> > (Al S-ro Del Ray: Fakte mi ne estas doktoro. "Ph. D."
> > nur estas mallongigo de mia nomo. Eble mi povus
> > uzi "Ph.D., B.S." sed tio sxajnas kiel ia sxerco.)
> >
> >
>
